instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Hello. 
I have this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A.
Initially turns on for 3 seconds and then off. Had a lot of liquid damage around and under <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>. I protected <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>, added flux and reflowed the area and cleaned with ultrasonic cleaner. 

Then the board had the same issue and I noticed that <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> was getting a little hot (noticed it with thermal camera) so I replaced it, after that <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> went to 4V so replaced <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is ok again but no green light and no attempt to turn on, just takes 37mA.

I reflowed the SMC and no change.

Any suggestion?


Thanks!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
What is the exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage?
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 12.65v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>: 0v

<TRANSISTOR>Q7820</TRANSISTOR>: 
Pin4: 3.3v
Pin3: 3.3v
Pin1:0v

<SIGNAL>P5V_3V3_SUS_EN</SIGNAL>: 4mV


Doubt: I have some differences on the names on the nets between the boardview and the schematic. Is that ok? Should I look for another version?
For example. <TRANSISTOR>Q7820</TRANSISTOR> Pin1is: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> on brd and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_FET</SIGNAL> on pdf.

According to the schematic they are the same right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Slight differences appear between Power FETs packages on Apple schematics and boardviews.
Use surrounding components to locate signals and power rails correctly.

Looks like missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_EN</SIGNAL>.
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> and PCH's RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Looks like SMC issue.
Reball it first; if still the same, change SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Ok, I will do it.

Can I replace the SMC of a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with the SMC of a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Reballing on the SMC worked but I have initial issue. Now I have green light, turns on, takes 231mA and then off.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Which voltages appear?
Do you get VCORE?
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> comes high?

Try to start in SMC bypass mode.
